page.title: Basic, Single-Clause Sentences - Examples
page.introduction: Sentences normally include some kind of inflection on the verbs and possibly agreement between the subject, object and verb. Some languages are pro-drop languages which allow a subject and/or object to be missing. In addition, think about whether there are any auxiliary elements that are separate words, and whether there can be more than one auxiliary element before the main verb. Examples of all of the above (except pro-drop) are given for English transitive single-clause sentences.

EnglishExample.exItem: The boy will hit the ball.
The boy might have hit the ball.
The boy might have been hitting the ball.

form.introduction: Ditransitives can have the second object expressed as a PP, as in English, or as a nominal phrase (DP). Some English examples of ditransitives are given below.

EnglishExample.exItem: The girl bought the present for her mother.
The man sold his car for two thousand dollars.

form.introduction: Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb. Motion verbs include a location in the form of either a PP or adverb. English examples include:

EnglishExample.exItem: My mother went to the store.

Most languages also have passive sentences, where the Theme or Patient fills the subject position. The Agent may be optionally expressed in some languages, but not allowed at all in others. If expressed, it may take the form of a PP (as in English with the particular preposition by) or a nominal phrase (DP), depending on the language. In addition, a particular auxiliary may be required in passives (a form of be in English). English examples, including some showing interaction with multiple auxiliaries are:

EnglishExample.exItem: The glass was broken by the child.
The ball might have been hit.
The ball might have been hit by the boy.
